articles.headline: Chinese Phrase Adds Mystery to Anbang’s About-Face on Starwood
articles.snippet: A vague Chinese regulation allows insurance companies to make overseas investments of less than 15 percent of their assets, but it has wiggle room.
articles.abstract: A vague Chinese regulation allows insurance companies to make overseas investments of less than 15 percent of their assets, but it has wiggle room.
articles.lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — An obscure phrase on foreign investment tucked into China’s insurance regulations is being viewed as stunningly cryptic by Western standards. But the collection of words — not even a full sentence — adds to the mystery surrounding the sudden decision by the Chinese insurer Anbang Insurance Group to walk away from  a $14 billion bid for the Starwood hotel chain.

articles.headline: Popular Quartz Countertops Pose a Risk to Workers
articles.snippet: The government has issued new rules on “engineered stone” containing silica, a mineral linked to silicosis and other diseases among workers.
articles.abstract: The government has issued new rules on “engineered stone” containing silica, a mineral linked to silicosis and other diseases among workers.
articles.lead_paragraph: As sleek “engineered stone” countertops grow in popularity, safety experts are warning that workers who handle them are at particularly high risk from an old workplace hazard — silica, the mineral tied to silicosis, a debilitating and potentially deadly lung disease.

articles.headline: Obama Rebukes Donald Trump’s Comments on Nuclear Weapons
articles.snippet: The president questioned Mr. Trump’s fitness for office in comments made after a meeting of more than 50 world leaders to discuss nuclear security.
articles.abstract: The president questioned Mr. Trump’s fitness for office in comments made after a meeting of more than 50 world leaders to discuss nuclear security.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama on Friday questioned Donald J. Trump’s fitness for office after statements from the Republican front-runner that the United States and its allies should move away from decades of constraints on the use of nuclear weapons. “We don’t want somebody in the Oval Office who doesn’t recognize how important that is,” Mr. Obama said.

articles.headline: Pabst Raids Dad’s Beer Fridge as It Looks to the Future
articles.snippet: A businessman who made a name for himself reviving Eastern European breweries has taken on an American project: Pabst Blue Ribbon.
articles.abstract: A businessman who made a name for himself reviving Eastern European breweries has taken on an American project: Pabst Blue Ribbon.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Eugene Kashper looks the part of someone who likes to throw back a few P.B.R.s from time to time — hipster glasses, scruffy facial hair, faded T-shirts and jeans and well-worn sneakers.

articles.headline: To Buy or Rent a Home? Weighing Which Is Better
articles.snippet: Arguments can be made for each option, but it’s impossible to know in advance which will provide better financial returns over time.
articles.abstract: Arguments can be made for each option, but it’s impossible to know in advance which will provide better financial returns over time.
articles.lead_paragraph: Rob Austin and his wife, Natalia, have a 10-month-old son, healthy incomes and plenty of cash in the bank for a down payment on a house. But they are happily renting a townhouse in Pasadena, Calif., with no plans to buy for now, given the frothy prices in their area.

articles.headline: North Carolina Law May Risk Federal Aid
articles.snippet: Billions of dollars for schools, highways and housing could be at risk as the Obama administration reviews the state’s new “bathroom law.”
articles.abstract: Billions of dollars for schools, highways and housing could be at risk as the Obama administration reviews the state’s new “bathroom law.”
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration is considering whether North Carolina’s new law on gay and transgender rights makes the state ineligible for billions of dollars in federal aid for schools, highways and housing, officials said Friday.
articles.byline: By Matt Apuzzo and Alan Blinder

articles.headline: Rift Among Navy SEALs Over Members Who Cash In on Brand
articles.snippet: The SEALs face a widening split over what many in the ranks describe as personal exploitation of a brotherhood that once prized discretion.
articles.abstract: The SEALs face a widening split over what many in the ranks describe as personal exploitation of a brotherhood that once prized discretion.
articles.lead_paragraph: Eric Greitens’s bid for governor of Missouri hinges on his experience as a Navy SEALs member, which he has chronicled in three books and promotes on his campaign web site, where he is pictured wearing his combat uniform, holding a rifle. “In the SEALs we learned, ‘there is no prize for second place in a gunfight,’ ” he said recently on Twitter.
articles.byline: By Nicholas Kulish, Christopher Drew and Sean D. Naylor

articles.headline: Obama Gets Scant Credit in Indiana Region Where Recovery Was Robust
articles.snippet: Few people are thanking the president for low unemployment. Instead, many discouraged workers are attracted to Donald J. Trump’s economic message.
articles.abstract: Few people are thanking the president for low unemployment. Instead, many discouraged workers are attracted to Donald J. Trump’s economic message.
articles.lead_paragraph: ELKHART, Ind. — Seven years ago President Obama came to this northern Indiana city, where unemployment was heading past 20 percent, for his first trip as president. Ed Neufeldt, the jobless man picked to introduce him, afterward donned three green rubber bracelets, each to be removed in turn as joblessness fell to 5 percent in the county, the state and the nation.

articles.headline: Guatemalan Women’s Claims Put Focus on Canadian Firms’ Conduct Abroad
articles.snippet: Overseas subsidiaries have long acted as a shield for extractive companies, but cases describing negligence and rape could lead to new scrutiny.
articles.abstract: Overseas subsidiaries have long acted as a shield for extractive companies, but cases describing negligence and rape could lead to new scrutiny.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOTE OCHO, Guatemala — Her husband was away in the fields, she said, when the truckloads of soldiers, police officers and mining security officials arrived. A half-dozen armed men swarmed into her one-room house, blocking her exit and helping themselves to the meal she had made for her children.

articles.headline: Electoral Map Is a Reality Check to Donald Trump’s Bid
articles.snippet: As Donald J. Trump moves closer to the Republican nomination, his unpopularity with large groups of voters suggests a potentially staggering loss in a general election.
articles.abstract: As Donald J. Trump moves closer to the Republican nomination, his unpopularity with large groups of voters suggests a potentially staggering loss in a general election.
articles.lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump’s presidential candidacy has stunned the Republican Party. But if he survives a late revolt by his rivals and other leaders to become the party’s standard-bearer in the general election, the electoral map now coming into view is positively forbidding.
articles.byline: By Jonathan Martin and Nate Cohn

articles.headline: Mikhail Lesin’s Strange Death in U.S. Follows a Fall From Russia’s Elite
articles.snippet: Mikhail Y. Lesin, once a player in the Kremlin’s media apparatus, was found dead from “blunt force injuries” in Washington, fueling speculation of murder.
articles.abstract: Mikhail Y. Lesin, once a player in the Kremlin’s media apparatus, was found dead from “blunt force injuries” in Washington, fueling speculation of murder.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As happens sometimes with wealthy Russians, Mikhail Y. Lesin found his business and political fortunes in Vladimir Putin’s Russia crumbling. Once an influential player in Mr. Putin’s rise to power, he was abruptly dismissed from his position in the Kremlin’s powerful media apparatus. Perhaps sensing that things could get worse, he seemed to be preparing for a new life in America.

articles.headline: The New Day, a British Upstart, Casts Its Fate to the Newsstand
articles.snippet: Britain’s newest newspaper doesn’t have a website or an app. Instead, its publisher believes that readers haven’t yet lost their appetite for newsprint.
articles.abstract: Britain’s newest newspaper doesn’t have a website or an app. Instead, its publisher believes that readers haven’t yet lost their appetite for newsprint.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARIS — The New Day, Britain’s youngest media start-up, has a little something for everyone: a digest of the day’s top news, human-interest features, coverage of popular culture, sports, health and travel, and even advice columnists.

articles.headline: Insider’s Account of How Graft Fed Brazil’s Political Crisis
articles.snippet: A leftist party led by Dilma Rousseff that rose to power vowing to stamp out the corruption of a privileged political elite ended up embracing its predecessors’ practices.
articles.abstract: A leftist party led by Dilma Rousseff that rose to power vowing to stamp out the corruption of a privileged political elite ended up embracing its predecessors’ practices.
articles.lead_paragraph: BRASÍLIA — The silver-haired senator from Brazil’s western frontier was still in his pajamas when federal police agents banged on the door of his suite at the Royal Tulip, the futuristic luxury hotel that serves as a bastion for much of Brazil’s political elite. It was 6 a.m.

articles.headline: Outshone by Smaller Screens, PCs Aim to Be Seen as Cool Again
articles.snippet: With the onslaught of smartphones and tablets, even people who depend on PCs now lack passion for these onetime miracle products.
articles.abstract: With the onslaught of smartphones and tablets, even people who depend on PCs now lack passion for these onetime miracle products.
articles.lead_paragraph: PALO ALTO, Calif. — Dion Weisler, the chief executive of HP Inc., recently held out a bulky laptop that was the pride of 2012. “This is the laptop we had when I came here,” he said.

articles.headline: Strategy on Garland: Act as Though He’ll Get Senate Hearing
articles.snippet: President Obama’s aides and Judge Merrick B. Garland’s allies have concluded that acting as if the Supreme Court nomination is going ahead is the best way to pressure adversaries.
articles.abstract: President Obama’s aides and Judge Merrick B. Garland’s allies have concluded that acting as if the Supreme Court nomination is going ahead is the best way to pressure adversaries.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Merrick B. Garland, chief judge of the United States Court of Appeals here, has been sequestered in a kind of alternate reality in a small conference room in the Eisenhower Executive Office Building next to the White House, cramming for questions from senators as if hearings on his nomination to the Supreme Court will happen this year.

articles.headline: China’s Companies Poised to Take Leap in Developing a Driverless Car
articles.snippet: Conditions for the technology may actually be more favorable in China than in the United States because of aggressive support from the government.
articles.abstract: Conditions for the technology may actually be more favorable in China than in the United States because of aggressive support from the government.
articles.lead_paragraph: Gansha Wu was a veteran engineering manager at Intel Corporation and director of Intel Labs China when two events upended his world last year.
articles.byline: By John Markoff and Paul Mozur

articles.headline: Drawing the Line on Gossip After the Gawker Trial
articles.snippet: Does the $140 million civil award against Gawker for its posting of a sex tape starring the retired wrestler Hulk Hogan mean that the culture as a whole is saying “Enough”?
articles.abstract: Does the $140 million civil award against Gawker for its posting of a sex tape starring the retired wrestler Hulk Hogan mean that the culture as a whole is saying “Enough”?
articles.lead_paragraph: The brand-new Gawker Media offices in downtown Manhattan are the bomb, as in great. They’re all glass and steel, clean lines and modern fixtures. They were paid for in secrets, exposed with a joyful ferocity that enriched Gawker’s founders and helped redefine how far our reality-TV culture could go to satisfy its appetite for gossip and news about the famous, the powerful and, increasingly, just the mildly interesting.

articles.headline: Washington Metro, 40 and Creaking, Stares at a Midlife Crisis
articles.snippet: Years of safety lapses as well as petty annoyances reveal how a grand vision of American liberalism has collided with reality.
articles.abstract: Years of safety lapses as well as petty annoyances reveal how a grand vision of American liberalism has collided with reality.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Jack Evans was a summer intern here in 1976, the year Metro, the capital region’s subway system, opened to rave reviews. It was an architectural triumph, with escalators that plunged into clean, well-lit stations — a mass transit marvel “like ‘The Jetsons,’ ” he says — a far cry from the graffiti-scarred, decrepit system of that era in New York.
articles.byline: By Sheryl Gay Stolberg and Nicholas Fandos

articles.headline: Early Missteps Seen as a Drag on Bernie Sanders’s Campaign
articles.snippet: Hillary Clinton appeared beatable in the race for the Democratic presidential nomination. But Mr. Sanders has failed to fully take advantage.
articles.abstract: Hillary Clinton appeared beatable in the race for the Democratic presidential nomination. But Mr. Sanders has failed to fully take advantage.
articles.lead_paragraph: The morning after he lost the Nevada caucuses in February, Bernie Sanders held a painful conference call with his top advisers.
articles.byline: By Patrick Healy and Yamiche Alcindor

articles.headline: As Messaging Apps Boom, Brands Tiptoe In
articles.snippet: Marketers are taking restrained approaches to advertising in apps to avoid antagonizing users, focusing less on overt promotion.
articles.abstract: Marketers are taking restrained approaches to advertising in apps to avoid antagonizing users, focusing less on overt promotion.
articles.lead_paragraph: Gatorade owns one of the iconic television moments of the Super Bowl, the dousing of the winning coach with a huge bucket of the sport drink, ice included. For the 2016 game, though, the brand wanted to reach more younger people, who tend to watch less TV.

articles.headline: Alaska Air Sees Virgin America as Key to West Coast
articles.snippet: Alaska Air Group is betting $2.6 billion that the airline industry is so consolidated after years of mergers that what it needs is another takeover.
articles.abstract: Alaska Air Group is betting $2.6 billion that the airline industry is so consolidated after years of mergers that what it needs is another takeover.
articles.lead_paragraph: In agreeing to buy Virgin America for $2.6 billion, Alaska Air Group is betting that the airline industry is so consolidated after years of mergers that what it needs is another takeover.
articles.byline: By Michael J. de la Merced and Chad Bray

articles.headline: Drones Marshaled to Drop Lifesaving Supplies Over Rwandan Terrain
articles.snippet: Zipline, a start-up based in California, raised $18 million and partnered with the small African country to shuttle packages of blood and emergency medicine.
articles.abstract: Zipline, a start-up based in California, raised $18 million and partnered with the small African country to shuttle packages of blood and emergency medicine.
articles.lead_paragraph: HALF MOON BAY, Calif. — From a bluff overlooking the Pacific Ocean, a loud pop signals the catapult launch of a small fixed-wing drone that is designed to carry medical supplies to remote locations almost 40 miles away.

articles.headline: As Pennsylvania Confronts Clergy Sex Abuse, Victims and Lawmakers Act
articles.snippet: Residents say they have been stunned to read evidence that priests they knew were secretly abusing children — findings a grand jury report called “staggering and sobering.”
articles.abstract: Residents say they have been stunned to read evidence that priests they knew were secretly abusing children — findings a grand jury report called “staggering and sobering.”
articles.lead_paragraph: LORETTO, Pa. — By the age of 12, Maureen Powers, the daughter of a professor at the local Roman Catholic university, played the organ in the magnificent hilltop Catholic basilica here and volunteered in the parish office. But, she said, she was hiding a secret: Her priest sexually abused her for two years, telling her it was for the purpose of “research.”

articles.headline: Michael C. Fina, Park Avenue Wedding Retailer, Bets on Amazon.com
articles.snippet: The luxury retailer known for wedding registry finery plans to close its sole brick-and-mortar store in Manhattan on April 16.
articles.abstract: The luxury retailer known for wedding registry finery plans to close its sole brick-and-mortar store in Manhattan on April 16.
articles.lead_paragraph: Michael C. Fina helped popularize bridal registries, and its Park Avenue store was a destination for Manhattan elites. It provided silver for John F. Kennedy’s inauguration festivities and catered to the likes of Frank Sinatra and Lennox Lewis.
articles.byline: By Hiroko Tabuchi and Nick Wingfield

articles.headline: Supreme Court Rejects Challenge on ‘One Person One Vote’
articles.snippet: The justices ruled unanimously that states may count all residents in drawing election districts. As a practical matter, the ruling mostly helped Democrats.
articles.abstract: The justices ruled unanimously that states may count all residents in drawing election districts. As a practical matter, the ruling mostly helped Democrats.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court  unanimously ruled on Monday that states may count all residents, whether or not they are eligible to vote, in drawing election districts. The decision was a major statement on the meaning of a fundamental principle of the American political system, that of “one person one vote.”
